pullRequest.title: Avoid unnecessary shuffling for single-input elementwise operations.
pullRequest.bodyText:
I was surprised there were two shuffles in our taxi dataframe example, this bug is why. This also exposed a bug with respect to the comparison methods.

Thank you for your contribution! Follow this checklist to help us incorporate your contribution quickly and easily:

 Choose reviewer(s) and mention them in a comment (R: @username).
 Format the pull request title like [BEAM-XXX] Fixes bug in ApproximateQuantiles, where you replace BEAM-XXX with the appropriate JIRA issue, if applicable. This will automatically link the pull request to the issue.
 Update CHANGES.md with noteworthy changes.
 If this contribution is large, please file an Apache Individual Contributor License Agreement.

See the Contributor Guide for more tips on how to make review process smoother.

commit.message:
Use non-underscore methods for series and dataframe comparators.

The underscore ones fail with error such as

"Can only compare identically-labeled Series objects"

when applied to collections whose rows have been permuted.
Only force indexing for multi-input elementwise operations.

beforeCommit.message: Only force indexing for multi-input elementwise operations.

afterCommit.message: Only force indexing for multi-input elementwise operations.

nodes.bodyText:
That's odd. So I guess series > other will be one place where we diverge from the Pandas API (in an easily documented way).
Is there a similar issue for arithmetic operations?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -1917,9 +1918,12 @@ def func(df, *args, **kwargs):
       '__i%s__' % base,
       frame_base._elementwise_method('__i%s__' % base, inplace=True))
 
-for name in ['__lt__', '__le__', '__gt__', '__ge__', '__eq__', '__ne__']:
-  setattr(DeferredSeries, name, frame_base._elementwise_method(name))
-  setattr(DeferredDataFrame, name, frame_base._elementwise_method(name))
+for name in ['lt', 'le', 'gt', 'ge', 'eq', 'ne']:
+  for p in '%s', '__%s__':
+    # Note that non-underscore name is used for both as the __xxx__ methods are
+    # order-sensitive.
